tit.cmt: As we are talking about a woman here, "empress" should be used to prevent confusion

sen.j: 推古天皇（すいこてんのう、欽明天皇15年（554年） - 推古天皇36年3月7日 (旧暦)（628年4月15日）『古事記』では戊子年3月15日）は、第33代の天皇（在位：崇峻天皇5年12月8日 (旧暦)（593年1月15日） - 推古天皇36年3月7日（628年4月15日）36年、『古事記』では37年）。
sen.e: Emperor Suiko (554 - April 15, 628), the thirty-third Emperor, was in the reign for 36 years from January 15, 593 to April 15, 628 or for 37 years according to "Kojiki" (the Records of Ancient Matters).
sen.cmt: 『古事記』・・・3月15日）は和歴のため、訳は省略しました。
sen.e: Empress Suiko (554 - April 15, 628), the thirty-third emperor of Japan, reigned for 36 years from January 15, 593 to April 15, 628, or for 37 years according to the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters).
sen.cmt: This seems a little odd as, unless I've got the maths wrong, 593 to 628 would give a reign of 25 years, wouldn't it?
sen.e: Empress Suiko (554 - April 15, 628), the thirty-third emperor of Japan, reigned for 36 years from January 15, 593 to April 15, 628, or for 37 years according to the "Kojiki" (Records of Ancient Matters).

sen.j: 日本初の女帝であると同時に、東アジア初の女性君主である。
sen.e: She was the first Empress in Japan as well as the first female monarch in east Asia.
She was the first empress of Japan, and the first female monarch in east Asia.
She was the first empress of Japan, and the first female monarch in east Asia.

sen.j: 額田部皇女（ぬかたべのひめみこ）。
sen.e: Nukatabe no Himemiko (the Imperial Princess Nukatabe).
Prior to her ascending the throne, her name was Nukatabe no Himemiko (Imperial Princess Nukatabe).
sen.cmt: I realize that the edited translation provides more information than the Japanese, but "Nukatabe no Himemiko (the Imperial Princess Nukatabe)" alone would leave the reader with no idea how this connects to the rest of the text. Please use full sentences when English style requires their use.
sen.e: Prior to her ascending the throne, her name was Nukatabe no Himemiko (Imperial Princess Nukatabe).

sen.j: 天皇号を初めて用いた日本の君主であり、「天皇」は現在、日本皇帝の一般的な呼称として定着している。
sen.e: She was the first monarch of Japan to use the Title of Tenno, which is now established as general naming for the Emperor of Japan.
She was the first monarch of Japan to use the title of "tenno," which has now become established as the general title for the emperor of Japan.
She was the first monarch of Japan to use the title of "tenno," which has now become established as the general title for the emperor of Japan.

sen.j: ただし、1998年の飛鳥池遺跡での天皇の文字を記した木簡が発見された以後は、天武天皇が最初の天皇号使用者との説が有力となっている。
sen.e: However, after a wooden tablet on which letters Tenno were written was found in the Asukaike Ruins in 1998, the theory has became prevailing that Emperor Temmu was the first user of the Title of Tenno.
However, after a wooden tablet with the letters, Tenno, was found in the Asukaike Ruins in 1998, a theory that says Emperor Temmu was the first to use the title Tenno has become predominant.
However, after a wooden tablet with the letters, Tenno, was found in the Asukaike Ruins in 1998, a theory that says Emperor Temmu was the first to use the title Tenno has become predominant.

sen.j: 『古事記』ではこの天皇までを記している。
sen.e: "Kojiki" describes things down to the era of this Emperor.
"Kojiki" includes issues down to the era of this Emperor.
sen.cmt: describes をincludesに、thingsをissuesにかえました。
sen.e: "Kojiki" includes issues down to the era of this Emperor.

sen.j: 日本の歴史の飛鳥時代の始まりはいつなのか諸説あるが、推古天皇の即位を基準にするのが一般的である。
sen.e: Although there are various theories as to when the Asuka period in the history of Japan began but it is general to regard enthronement of Emperor Suiko as the beginning.
Although there are various theories as to when the Asuka period in the history of Japan began but it is general to regard enthronement of Emperor Suiko as the beginning.
Although there are various theories as to when the Asuka period in the history of Japan began but it is general to regard enthronement of Emperor Suiko as the beginning.

sen.j: 日本に伝来した仏教文化が本格的に華開いた時代であり、これを飛鳥文化という。
sen.e: It was a period when the Buddhist culture that was introduced to Japan blossomed fully and this culture is referred to as the Asuka culture.
It was a period when the Buddhist culture that was introduced to Japan blossomed fully and this culture is referred to as the Asuka culture.
It was a period when the Buddhist culture that was introduced to Japan blossomed fully and this culture is referred to as the Asuka culture.

sen.j: 妹（いも）、豊御食炊屋比売（とよみけかしぎやひめ）命、小治田（をはりだ）宮に坐しまして、天の下治らしめすこと、三十七歳（みそじまりななとせ）なりき。
sen.e: She, Toyomikekashigiyahime (the Emperor Suiko's name in Kojiki), resided in the Imperial Palace of Owarida and ruled the country for 37 years.
sen.cmt: ①「妹」は広辞苑によると「男が女を親しんで言う語」とありますが、ここで単純に she と訳しました。②死亡年月日は第1節の新暦年月日に合わせました。
sen.e: She, Toyomikekashigiyahime (the Emperor Suiko's name in Kojiki), resided in the Imperial Palace of Owarida and ruled the country for 37 years.
She, Toyomikekashigiyahime (the Emperor Suiko's name in Kojiki), resided in the Imperial Palace of Owarida and ruled the country for 37 years.

sen.j: （分注、戊子の年の三月十五日癸丑の日に崩りましき）。
sen.e: (Note: she passed away on April 15, 628).
(Note: she passed away on April 15, 628).
(Note: she passed away on April 15, 628).

sen.j: 御陵は大野の岡の上にありしを、後に科長（しなが）の大木陵に遷しき。
sen.e: The Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) was on the hill of Ono, which was later moved to Oki no Misasagi in Shinaga.
sen.cmt: 「大木陵」の大木は地名と解釈しました。
sen.e: The Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) was on the hill of Ono, which was later moved to Oki no Misasagi in Shinaga.
The Misasagi (Imperial mausoleum) was on the hill of Ono, which was later moved to Oki no Misasagi in Shinaga.
("Kojiki")
("Kojiki")
("Kojiki")

sen.j: 小治田宮は奈良県高市郡。
sen.e: The Imperial Palace of Owarida was located in Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
The Imperial Palace of Owarida was located in Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.
The Imperial Palace of Owarida was located in Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 『古事記』
sen.e: "Kojiki":
"Kojiki"
"Kojiki"

sen.j: - 豊御食炊屋比売命
sen.e: Toyomikekashigiyahime.
sen.cmt: 読み方は用語集に従いました。
sen.e: Toyomikekashigiyahime.
Toyomikekashigiyahime.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』
sen.e: "Nihonshoki"(Chronicles of Japan):
"Nihonshoki"(Chronicles of Japan):
"Nihonshoki"(Chronicles of Japan):

sen.j: - 豊御食炊屋姫尊
sen.e: Toyomikekashikiyahime no mikoto.
sen.cmt: 読み方は用語集に従いました。
sen.e: Toyomikekashikiyahime no mikoto.
Toyomikekashikiyahime no mikoto.

sen.j: 第29代欽明天皇の皇女で、母は大臣 (日本)蘇我稲目の女蘇我堅塩媛。
sen.e: She was the princess of the twenty-ninth Emperor Kinmei, her mother being SOGA no Kitashihime, a daughter of the minister, SOGA no Iname.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明。大臣（日本）（おおおみ）は the minister と訳しました。
sen.e: She was the princess of the twenty-ninth Emperor Kinmei, her mother being SOGA no Kitashihime, a daughter of the minister, SOGA no Iname.
She was the princess of the twenty-ninth Emperor Kinmei, her mother being SOGA no Kitashihime, a daughter of the minister, SOGA no Iname.

sen.j: 第31代用明天皇は同母兄、第32代崇峻天皇は異母弟。
sen.e: The thirty-first Emperor Yomei was her elder brother and the thirty-second Emperor Sushun was her younger paternal half-brother.
The thirty-first Emperor Yomei was her elder brother and the thirty-second Emperor Sushun was her younger paternal half-brother.
The thirty-first Emperor Yomei was her elder brother and the thirty-second Emperor Sushun was her younger paternal half-brother.

sen.j: 蘇我馬子は母方の叔父。
sen.e: SOGA no Umako was her maternal uncle.
SOGA no Umako was her maternal uncle.
SOGA no Umako was her maternal uncle.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』に「姿色端麗・進止軌制」（「姿色（みかお）端麗（きらきら）しく」、挙措動作は乱れなくととのって（進止軌制）いた）と記される。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki," it is described that she was fair of face and figure, and was well-mannered and polite.
In "Nihonshoki," it is described that 'she was fair of face and figure, and was well-mannered and polite.'
In "Nihonshoki," it is described that 'she was fair of face and figure, and was well-mannered and polite.'

sen.j: 欽明天皇32年（571年）に異母兄・渟中倉太珠敷皇子（第30代敏達天皇）の妃となる。
sen.e: In 571, she became the wife of Prince NUNAKAKURA no Futomashiki (the thirtieth Emperor Bidatsu), her elder paternal half-brother.
In 571, she became the wife of Prince NUNAKAKURA no Futomashiki (the thirtieth Emperor Bidatsu), her elder paternal half-brother.
In 571, she became the wife of Prince NUNAKAKURA no Futomashiki (the thirtieth Emperor Bidatsu), her elder paternal half-brother.

sen.j: 敏達天皇5年3月（576年）、皇后広姫の逝去を承け皇后に立てられ、敏達14年8月乙酉朔己亥（8月15日 (旧暦)）（585年9月15日）、35歳のとき、敏達天皇が没した。
sen.e: In 576, upon the death of Empress Hirohime, she was named the Empress and, on September 15, 585 when she was 35 years old, the Emperor Bidatsu passed away.
sen.cmt: 定訳不明。「広姫」は「ひろひめ」と読むものと解釈しました。
sen.e: In 576, upon the death of Empress Hirohime, she was named the empress and, on September 15, 585 when she was 35 years old, the Emperor Bidatsu passed away.
In 576, upon the death of Empress Hirohime, she was named the empress and, on September 15, 585 when she was 35 years old, the Emperor Bidatsu passed away.

sen.j: ただし、『日本書紀』推古紀によれば18歳で皇后に立てられたとあり、これを採用した場合には欽明天皇32年（敏達天皇即位の年）に皇后となったことになり、広姫立后の記事と矛盾することになり、広姫立后記事か推古の立后時の年齢のいずれかが誤りの可能性がある。
sen.e: However, according to the chronicle of Suiko in "Nihonshoki," she was named the Empress at the age of 18 and, when this theory is employed, she became the Empress in 571, the year of enthronement of Emperor Bidatsu, contradicting an article on investiture of Hirohime as the Empress and suggesting a possible mistake either in the article on investiture of Hirohime as the Empress or the age of Suiko at the time of her investiture as the Empress.

However, according to the chronicle of Suiko in "Nihonshoki," she was named the empress at the age of 18 and, when this theory is adopted, she became the empress in 571, the year of enthronement of Emperor Bidatsu, contradicting an article on investiture of Hirohime as the empress and suggesting a possible mistake either in the article on investiture of Hirohime as the empress or the age of Suiko at the time of her investiture as the empress.

However, according to the chronicle of Suiko in "Nihonshoki," she was named the empress at the age of 18 and, when this theory is adopted, she became the empress in 571, the year of enthronement of Emperor Bidatsu, contradicting an article on investiture of Hirohime as the empress and suggesting a possible mistake either in the article on investiture of Hirohime as the empress or the age of Suiko at the time of her investiture as the empress.

sen.j: 菟道貝蛸皇女（聖徳太子妃）、竹田皇子、小墾田皇女（押坂彦人大兄皇子妃）、尾張皇子（聖徳太子の妃橘大郎女の父）、田眼皇女（田村皇子（後の舒明天皇）妃）ら二男五女をもうけた。
sen.e: She gave birth to two sons and five daughters including Princess Ujinokaitako (the wife of Prince Shotoku), Prince Takeda, Princess Oharida (the wife of OSHISAKA no Hikohito no Oenomiko), Prince Owari (the father of TACHIBANA no Oiratsume, the wife of Prince Shotoku), Princess Tame (the wife of Prince Tamura-later Emperor Jomei), etc.
sen.cmt: 「田眼皇女」は（ためのひめみこ）と読むため、Princess Tame と訳しました（古代史主要人物事典ーYahoo Japan)。
sen.e: She gave birth to two sons and five daughters including Princess Ujinokaitako (the wife of Prince Shotoku), Prince Takeda, Princess Oharida (the wife of OSHISAKA no Hikohito no Oenomiko), Prince Owari (the father of TACHIBANA no Oiratsume, the wife of Prince Shotoku), Princess Tame (the wife of Prince Tamura-later Emperor Jomei), etc.

She gave birth to two sons and five daughters including Princess Ujinokaitako (the wife of Prince Shotoku), Prince Takeda, Princess Oharida (the wife of OSHISAKA no Hikohito no Oenomiko), Prince Owari (the father of TACHIBANA no Oiratsume, the wife of Prince Shotoku), Princess Tame (the wife of Prince Tamura-later Emperor Jomei), etc.

sen.j: 用明元年夏5月（586年）、殯に穴穂部皇子が侵入し、皇后は寵臣三輪逆に助けられたが、逆の方は殺されるはめとなった。
sen.e: In May 586, Prince Anahobe broke in hinkyu (the funeral parlor) and the Empress was saved by her favorite retainer, MIWA no Sakau, who found himself being killed.
sen.cmt: 「殯」は「殯宮」と同義と解釈しました。
sen.e: In May 586, Prince Anahobe broke in hinkyu (the funeral parlor) and the Empress was saved by her favorite retainer, MIWA no Sakau, who found himself being killed.
In May 586, Prince Anahobe broke in hinkyu (the funeral parlor) and the Empress was saved by her favorite retainer, MIWA no Sakau, who found himself being killed.

sen.j: その後、用明天皇が2年ほど皇位に在ったが、用明2年4月乙巳朔癸丑（旧暦4月9日 (旧暦)『古事記』では4月15日 (旧暦)）（587年）に病没後、穴穂部皇子を推す物部守屋と泊瀬部皇子を支持する蘇我馬子が戦い、蘇我氏の勝利に終わった。
sen.e: Thereafter, the Emperor Yomei held the Imperial Throne for about 2 years but, after he died of illness on May 21, 587, MONONOBE no Moriya, who endorsed Prince Anahobe, and SOGA no Umako, who supported Prince Hatsusebe, fought, ending in the victory of the Soga clan.
sen.cmt: 旧暦を西暦へ変換する時の西暦は、グレゴリオ歴ではなく、ユリウス暦としました。これは第1節の推古36年3月7日の変換で妥当性を確認しました。
sen.e: Thereafter, Emperor Yomei held the Imperial Throne for about 2 years but, after he died of illness on May 21, 587, MONONOBE no Moriya, who endorsed Prince Anahobe, fought with SOGA no Umako, who supported Prince Hatsusebe, ending in the victory of the Soga clan.

Thereafter, Emperor Yomei held the Imperial Throne for about 2 years but, after he died of illness on May 21, 587, MONONOBE no Moriya, who endorsed Prince Anahobe, fought with SOGA no Umako, who supported Prince Hatsusebe, ending in the victory of the Soga clan.

sen.j: そこで敏達皇太后が詔を下して泊瀬部皇子（崇峻天皇）に即位を命じたという。
sen.e: It is said that the Empress Dowager Bidatsu therefore issued an imperial edict ordering Prince Hatsusebe (Emperor Sushun) to be enthroned.
It is said that Empress Dowager Bidatsu therefore issued an imperial edict ordering Prince Hatsusebe (Emperor Sushun) to be enthroned.
It is said that Empress Dowager Bidatsu therefore issued an imperial edict ordering Prince Hatsusebe (Emperor Sushun) to be enthroned.

sen.j: しかし、5年後の祟峻5年11月癸卯朔乙巳（旧暦11月3日 (旧暦)）（592年）には崇峻天皇が馬子の指図によって暗殺されてしまい、翌月である12月壬申朔己卯（旧暦12月8日 (旧暦)）に、先々代の皇后であった額田部皇女が、馬子に請われて、豊浦宮において即位した。
sen.e: However, after five years, on December 12, 592, the Emperor Sushun was assassinated by the instruction of Umako and next month, on January 15, 593, Princess Nukatabe, the Empress-before-last, was begged by Umako to be enthroned at the Imperial Palace of Toyoura.

However, after five years, on December 12, 592, Emperor Sushun was assassinated by instruction of Umako and next month, on January 15, 593, Princess Nukatabe, the empress-before-last, was begged by Umako to be enthroned at the Imperial Palace of Toyoura.

However, after five years, on December 12, 592, Emperor Sushun was assassinated by instruction of Umako and next month, on January 15, 593, Princess Nukatabe, the empress-before-last, was begged by Umako to be enthroned at the Imperial Palace of Toyoura.

sen.j: 時に彼女は39歳で、史上初の女帝となった（ただし、神功皇后と飯豊青皇女を歴代から除外した場合）。
sen.e: At that time, she was 39 years old and became the first female monarch in history (however, this is so when Empress Jingu and Crown Princess Iitoyo are excluded).
At that time, she was 39 years old and became the first female monarch in history (however, this is the case when Empress Jingu and Crown Princess Iitoyo are excluded).
At that time, she was 39 years old and became the first female monarch in history (however, this is the case when Empress Jingu and Crown Princess Iitoyo are excluded).

sen.j: その背景には皇太后が実子の竹田皇子の擁立を願ったものの、敏達の最初の皇后が生んだ押坂彦人大兄皇子（舒明天皇の父）の擁立論が蘇我氏に反対する勢力を中心に強まったために、馬子と皇太后がその動きを抑えるために竹田皇子への中継ぎとして即位したのだと言われている（だが、竹田皇子は間もなく死去してしまう）。
sen.e: Behind this, there is a story that the Empress Dowager hoped for enthronement of her biological son Prince Takeda, but because an opinion for enthronement of OSHISAKA no Hikohito no Oenomiko became stronger, centering around the opponents of the Soga clan and, in order to suppress that movement, Umako and the Empress Dowager decided that she be enthroned (however, before long, Prince Takeda passed away).

Behind this, there is a story that the Empress Dowager hoped for enthronement of her biological son Prince Takeda, but because an opinion for enthronement of OSHISAKA no Hikohito no Oenomiko became stronger, centering around the opponents of the Soga clan and, in order to suppress that movement, Umako and the Empress Dowager decided that she be enthroned (however, before long, Prince Takeda passed away).

Behind this, there is a story that the Empress Dowager hoped for enthronement of her biological son Prince Takeda, but because an opinion for enthronement of OSHISAKA no Hikohito no Oenomiko became stronger, centering around the opponents of the Soga clan and, in order to suppress that movement, Umako and the Empress Dowager decided that she be enthroned (however, before long, Prince Takeda passed away).

sen.j: 翌年（593年）4月10日 (旧暦)、甥の厩戸皇子（聖徳太子）を皇太子として万機を摂行させた。
sen.e: On May 15, 593, she appointed her nephew, Prince Umayado (Prince Shotoku), as the Crown Prince and let him administer the critical affairs of state as a proxy.
On May 15, 593, she appointed her nephew, Prince Umayado (Prince Shotoku), as the Crown Prince and let him administer the critical affairs of state as a proxy.
On May 15, 593, she appointed her nephew, Prince Umayado (Prince Shotoku), as the Crown Prince and let him administer the critical affairs of state as a proxy.

sen.j: 厩戸の父は推古天皇の同母兄の用明天皇、母も異母妹（かつ生母同士が実の姉妹関係）の間柄であり、竹田皇子亡き後において厩戸が天皇にとって最も信頼のおける血縁者であったからだと見られている。
sen.e: This is thought to be because of a relationship that the father of Umayado was her elder brother, Emperor Yomei, and also his mother was her younger paternal half-sister (and their biological mothers were sisters), and thus Umayado was her most trustworthy relative.

This is thought to be because of a relationship that the father of Umayado was her elder brother, Emperor Yomei, and also his mother was her younger paternal half-sister (and their biological mothers were sisters), and thus Umayado was her most trustworthy relative.

This is thought to be because of a relationship that the father of Umayado was her elder brother, Emperor Yomei, and also his mother was her younger paternal half-sister (and their biological mothers were sisters), and thus Umayado was her most trustworthy relative.

sen.j: コーネル大学のアジア研究者ジョーン・ピゴットは、このような女性天皇と男性摂政というとりあわせを、祭祀の責務と行政の責務のあいだの対位法的な関係をベースにした相補型の共同統治であると述べている。
sen.e: Joan R. Piggott, a scholar of Asian studies at Cornell University, describes this combination of a female Emperor and a male regent as a complimentary type condominium based on a contrapuntal relationship between a responsibility of a religious service and a responsibility of public administration.

Joan R. Piggott, a scholar of Asian studies at Cornell University, describes this combination of a female Emperor and a male regent as a complimentary type condominium based on a contrapuntal relationship between a responsibility of a religious service and a responsibility of public administration.

Joan R. Piggott, a scholar of Asian studies at Cornell University, describes this combination of a female Emperor and a male regent as a complimentary type condominium based on a contrapuntal relationship between a responsibility of a religious service and a responsibility of public administration.

sen.j: シカゴ大学名誉教授で宗教史学者のジョゼフ・キタガワは、シャーマン的能力の持ち主で、血縁の男性を介して長期間の統治を行った受動的な女性最高権者である点が、邪馬台国の卑弥呼に似ていると述べている。
sen.e: Joseph M. Kitagawa, a professor emeritus and a historian of religion at University of Chicago, describes that she resembles Himiko of Yamatai-Koku Kingdom in that she had a shamanistic ability and was the highest authority holder who was passive and female, and governed the country for a long time through a consanguine man.

Joseph M. Kitagawa, a professor emeritus and a historian of religion at University of Chicago, describes that she resembles Himiko of Yamatai-Koku Kingdom in that she had a shamanistic ability and was the highest authority holder who was passive and female, and governed the country for a long time through a consanguine man.

Joseph M. Kitagawa, a professor emeritus and a historian of religion at University of Chicago, describes that she resembles Himiko of Yamatai-Koku Kingdom in that she had a shamanistic ability and was the highest authority holder who was passive and female, and governed the country for a long time through a consanguine man.

sen.j: 推古天皇は頭脳明晰な人で、皇太子と大臣馬子の勢力のバランスをとり、豪族の反感を買わぬように、巧みに王権の存続を図った。
sen.e: Emperor Suiko was a brilliant person and balanced the influences of the Crown Prince and the minister Umako, so as not to provoke antipathy of Gozoku (local ruling families), and labored skillfully for the endurance of sovereignty.

Emperor Suiko was a bright person who balanced the influences of the Crown Prince and the minister Umako, so as not to provoke antipathy of Gozoku (local ruling families), and labored skillfully for the endurance of sovereignty.
sen.cmt: 明晰=brightにしました。Andをwhoにかえました。
sen.e: Emperor Suiko was a bright person who balanced the influences of the Crown Prince and the minister Umako, so as not to provoke antipathy of Gozoku (local ruling families), and labored skillfully for the endurance of sovereignty.

sen.j: 在位中は蘇我氏の最盛期であるが、帝は外戚で重臣の馬子に対しても、国家の利益を損じてまで譲歩した事がなかった。
sen.e: During her reign, when the Soga clan was at the height of its prosperity, the Emperor did not go as far as to damage the interest of the country by compromising even with Umako, her maternal relative and a senior vassal.

During her reign, when the Soga clan was at the height of its prosperity, the Emperor did not go as far as to damage the interest of the country by compromising even with Umako, her maternal relative and a senior vassal.

During her reign, when the Soga clan was at the height of its prosperity, the Emperor did not go as far as to damage the interest of the country by compromising even with Umako, her maternal relative and a senior vassal.

sen.j: ずっと後のことではあるが、推古天皇32年（624年）、馬子が葛城県（馬子の本居（ウブスナ）とされる）の支配権を望んだ時、女帝は、「あなたは私の叔父ではあるが、だからといって、公の土地を私人に譲ってしまっては、後世の人には私が愚かな女だといわれ、一方であなたも、不忠だと謗られよう」と言って、この要求を拒絶したという。
sen.e: It is said that, long afterward in 624, when Umako hoped for the right to rule Katsuragi-ken Prefecture (which is said to be Umako's birthplace), she refused this demand by saying that "even though you are my uncle, if I donate a public land to a private person, the future generation will call me a foolish woman and, on the other hand, they will criticize you as being disloyal."

It is said that, long afterward in 624, when Umako hoped for the right to rule Katsuragi-ken Prefecture (which is said to be Umako's birthplace), she refused this demand by saying that "even though you are my uncle, if I donate a public land to a private person, the future generation will call me a foolish woman and, on the other hand, they will criticize you as being disloyal."

It is said that, long afterward in 624, when Umako hoped for the right to rule Katsuragi-ken Prefecture (which is said to be Umako's birthplace), she refused this demand by saying that "even though you are my uncle, if I donate a public land to a private person, the future generation will call me a foolish woman and, on the other hand, they will criticize you as being disloyal."

tit.e: Japanese Envoy to Sui Dynasty China
Japanese Envoy to Sui Dynasty in China
Japanese Envoy to Sui Dynasty in China

sen.j: このように、公正な女帝の治世のもと、聖徳太子はその才能を十分に発揮し、冠位十二階（603年）・十七条憲法（604年）を次々に制定して、法令・組織の整備を進めた。
sen.e: As described above, under fair reign of the Empress, Prince Shotoku fully exhibited his ability and enacted Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) (in 603) and Seventeen-Article Constitution (in 604) one after another to carry out improvement of laws and organizations.

As described above, under fair reign of the Empress, Prince Shotoku fully exhibited his ability and enacted Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) (in 603) and Seventeen-Article Constitution (in 604) one after another to carry out improvement of laws and organizations.

As described above, under fair reign of the Empress, Prince Shotoku fully exhibited his ability and enacted Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) (in 603) and Seventeen-Article Constitution (in 604) one after another to carry out improvement of laws and organizations.

sen.j: 推古天皇15年（607年）、小野妹子を隋に派遣した。
sen.e: In 607, ONO no Imoko was sent to Sui.
In 607, ONO no Imoko was sent to Sui.
In 607, ONO no Imoko was sent to Sui.

sen.j: （実際には、俀国が６００年に遣隋使をおくっている。)
sen.e: (In fact, Wakoku sent an envoy to Sui in 600.
(In fact, Wakoku sent an envoy to Sui in 600.
(In fact, Wakoku sent an envoy to Sui in 600.

sen.j: (また、これは１２年の誤差があり遣唐使の可能性もある。）。
sen.e: In addition, this date has an error of 12 years and, thus, this might have been an envoy to Tang Dynasty China.)
In addition, this date has an error of 12 years and, thus, this might have been an envoy to Tang in China.)
In addition, this date has an error of 12 years and, thus, this might have been an envoy to Tang in China.)

sen.j: 中国皇帝から政権の正統性を付与してもらう目的で、過去にもたびたび使節が派遣されていたが、初めて日本の独立性を強調する目的で使節が派遣された。
sen.e: For the purpose of having orthodoxy granted by an emperor of China, there had often been envoys sent in the past but, for the first time, there was sent an envoy in order to emphasize independence of Japan.

For the purpose of having orthodoxy granted by an emperor of China, there had often been envoys sent in the past but, for the first time, they were sent as an envoy in order to emphasize independence of Japan.

For the purpose of having orthodoxy granted by an emperor of China, there had often been envoys sent in the past but, for the first time, they were sent as an envoy in order to emphasize independence of Japan.

sen.j: 翌年からは入隋の使節に学問生・学問僧を同行させた。
sen.e: From the next year, the envoy to Sui was accompanied by scholars and trainee monks.
From the next year, the envoy to Sui was accompanied by scholars and trainee monks.
From the next year, the envoy to Sui was accompanied by scholars and trainee monks.

sen.j: また、推古天皇二年に出された、三宝（仏・法・僧）を敬うべしという詔が示しているように、女帝は太子や馬子と共に仏法興隆にも努め、斑鳩に法隆寺を建立させたりした。
sen.e: Also, as the imperial decree issued in 594 that Sanbo (three treasures of Buddhism; Buddha, sutras and priesthood) should be respected shows, the Empress, together with the Prince and Umako, tried to make Buddhism flourish and let Horyu-ji Temple built in Ikaruga (a town in Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture).

Also, as the imperial decree issued in 594 which says that Sanbo (three treasures of Buddhism; Buddha, sutras and priesthood) should be respected shows, the Empress, together with the Prince and Umako, tried to make Buddhism flourish and let Horyu-ji Temple to be built in Ikaruga (a town in Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture).

Also, as the imperial decree issued in 594 which says that Sanbo (three treasures of Buddhism; Buddha, sutras and priesthood) should be respected shows, the Empress, together with the Prince and Umako, tried to make Buddhism flourish and let Horyu-ji Temple to be built in Ikaruga (a town in Ikoma-gun, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 推古天皇28年（620年）、聖徳太子と馬子は『天皇記』『国記』を編纂して献上したが、2年後には太子が49歳で薨去し、4年後、蘇我馬子も亡くなった。
sen.e: In 620, Prince Shotoku and Umako compiled "Tennoki" (a Record of Emperors) and "a National Record "and donated them to the Empress but, two years later, the Prince passed away at the age of 49 and after 4 years, SOGA no Umako also died.

In 620, Prince Shotoku and Umako compiled "Tennoki" (a Record of Emperors) and "a National Record "and donated them to the Empress but, two years later, the Prince passed away at the age of 49 and after 4 years, SOGA no Umako also died.

In 620, Prince Shotoku and Umako compiled "Tennoki" (a Record of Emperors) and "a National Record "and donated them to the Empress but, two years later, the Prince passed away at the age of 49 and after 4 years, SOGA no Umako also died.

sen.j: 長年国政を任せてきた重臣を次々に失った女帝の心境は、老いが深まるにつれ寂寥なものであったに違いない。
sen.e: The mind-set of the Empress, who lost her senior vassals one after another whom she let handle the affairs of state, must have been lonely as she grew older.
The mind-set of the Empress, who lost her senior vassals one after another, whom she let handle the affairs of state, must have been lonely as she grew older.
The mind-set of the Empress, who lost her senior vassals one after another, whom she let handle the affairs of state, must have been lonely as she grew older.

sen.j: 推古天皇36年3月7日（628年4月15日）、75歳で小墾田宮において崩御。
sen.e: On April 15, 628, she passed away at the Imperial residence of Oharida at the age of 75.
On April 15, 628, she passed away at the Imperial residence of Oharida at the age of 75.
On April 15, 628, she passed away at the Imperial residence of Oharida at the age of 75.

sen.j: 死の前日に、女帝は敏達天皇の嫡孫・田村皇子を枕元に呼び、謹しんで物事を明察するように諭し、さらに聖徳太子の子山背大兄王にも、他人の意見を納れるように誡めただけで、後継者の指名は避けたようである。
sen.e: A day before her death, the Empress summoned Prince Tamura, the legitimate grandchild of Emperor Bidatsu, to her bedside and admonished him to see things through respectfully and also rebuked Prince YAMASHIRO no Oe to listen to opinions of other people, apparently avoiding appointment of her successor.

A day before her death, the Empress summoned Prince Tamura, the legitimate grandchild of Emperor Bidatsu, to her bedside and admonished him to see things through respectfully and also rebuked Prince YAMASHIRO no Oe to listen to opinions of other people, apparently avoiding appointment of her successor.

A day before her death, the Empress summoned Prince Tamura, the legitimate grandchild of Emperor Bidatsu, to her bedside and admonished him to see things through respectfully and also rebuked Prince YAMASHIRO no Oe to listen to opinions of other people, apparently avoiding appointment of her successor.

sen.j: 陵墓
sen.e: Imperial Mausoleum
Imperial Mausoleum
Imperial Mausoleum

sen.j: 日本の歴史書である『古事記』には、「その年の9月20日 (旧暦)に喪礼が執り行われ、遺令によって女帝の亡骸は息子・竹田皇子が眠る墓に合葬された。
sen.e: According to "Kojiki," a Japanese history book, "the funeral rites were conducted on October 23, 628 and, according to the posthumous order, her remains were buried in the tomb where her son, Prince Tamura, slept.

According to "Kojiki," a Japanese history book, 'the funeral rites were conducted on October 23, 628 and, according to the posthumous order, her remains were buried in the tomb where her son, Prince Tamura, slept.

According to "Kojiki," a Japanese history book, 'the funeral rites were conducted on October 23, 628 and, according to the posthumous order, her remains were buried in the tomb where her son, Prince Tamura, slept.

sen.j: その所在は奈良県橿原市五条野の植山古墳とされている。
sen.e: Its whereabouts is said to be at the Ueyama Tumulus located at Gojono, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Its whereabouts is said to be at the Ueyama Tumulus located at Gojono, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.
Its whereabouts is said to be at the Ueyama Tumulus located at Gojono, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 後年、時期は不明ながら、大阪府南河内郡太子町山田にある河内国磯長山田陵（しながのやまだのみささぎ、考古学名としては山田高塚古墳）に改葬された」とある。
sen.e: In later years, though not known when, she was reburied in Shinaga no Yamada no Misasagi (the Yamada Imperial tomb in Shinaga; by an archeological term, Yamada Takatsuka Tumulus) located at Yamada, Taishi-cho, Minami Kawachi-gun, Osaka Prefecture.'

In later years, though not known when, she was reburied in Shinaga no Yamada no Misasagi (the Yamada Imperial tomb in Shinaga; by an archeological term, Yamada Takatsuka Tumulus) located at Yamada, Taishi-cho, Minami Kawachi-gun, Osaka Prefecture.'

In later years, though not known when, she was reburied in Shinaga no Yamada no Misasagi (the Yamada Imperial tomb in Shinaga; by an archeological term, Yamada Takatsuka Tumulus) located at Yamada, Taishi-cho, Minami Kawachi-gun, Osaka Prefecture.'
